column2: When it comes to pulling off coups in 2021, Donald Trump is 0 for 2. The latest, of course, being his failed effort to depose Senate Minority Leader Mitch McConnell. I recently documented how Trumpâ€™s political endorsements donâ€™t matter much in the outside game of GOP primary elections. It turns out, neither do his condemnations in the inside game of Senate leadership contests. At least, thatâ€™s what this Politico headline suggests: â€œGOP blows off Trumpâ€™s bid to oust McConnell.â€ As the story recounts, Trump has tried in vain to topple McConnellâ€”likely as retribution for McConnellâ€™s decision to acknowledge Joe Bidenâ€™s victory. McConnellâ€™s blistering comments about the Jan. 6 attack accelerated Trumpâ€™s fervor (ironically, after McConnell voted not to convict Trump in his second impeachment trial). But Trump has recently turned up the heat. â€œHow this guy can stay as Leader is beyond comprehension,â€ Trump recently wrote. â€œ[T]his is coming not only from me, but from virtually everyone in the Republican Party. He is a disaster and should be replaced as â€˜Leaderâ€™ ASAP!â€ The only problem? No sitting Republican Senators agree with Trump, and only two Republican candidates for Senate (Alaskaâ€™s Kelly Tshibaka and Missouriâ€™s Eric Greitens) have endorsed this notion. Old Man Trump Is Looking Weaker and Weakerâ€”Sad! It would be a mistake to read too much into this. As conservative writer Ramesh Ponnuru noted, despite documented signs of weakness within the GOP, â€œTrump retains great strength in the party and remains its most powerful leaderâ€ and, simultaneously â€œis also stronger than he looks.â€ This paradox rings true: Trump is the obvious frontrunner to win the Republican presidential nomination in 2024, and he clearly lacks the authority to persuade or impose his will in other ways. He is powerful and talented, but also lazy and incompetent. Put otherwise, he is formidable but not unbeatable. Seeing his enemies prosper is a potent reminder of this. If â€œthe best revenge is living well,â€ McConnell is ending his year on a high note. Just this week, Joe Biden and Chuck Schumer had to abandon trying to pass Build Back Better any time soon (Democratsâ€™ plans to pass the social spending bill have been stymied by Sen. Joe Manchinâ€”who just so happens to have met with McConnell on Thursday). Also this week, McConnell took the arrows on raising the debt limit, helping the country avoid default, while preventing any Republicans from being implicated in the vote. It was the sort of servant leadership that engenders loyalty among the ranksâ€”a smart political move for a party poised to take back the majority next year. While Trump may be hard to stop in 2024, McConnell (who already holds the record for a Republican leader) is on a path to become the longest-serving party leader in Senate history in 2023, when he would break Sen. Mike Mansfieldâ€™s sixteen-year record. In a political environment where such feats of longevity seem unthinkable, McConnell (who has been unanimously elected leader by his caucus every two years since 2006) is as good at the inside game of politics as Trump is at gaslighting Republican voters. And while McConnell may not be looking to start a direct fight with Trump, heâ€™s clearly not above trolling him. Take, for instance, his comments this week about the Houseâ€™s Jan. 6 commission. â€œI think the fact finding is interesting. Weâ€™re all going to be watching it,â€ McConnell told Spectrum News. â€œIt was a horrendous event, and I think what theyâ€™re seeking to find out is something the public needs to know.â€ Similarly, he told CNN: â€œIt will be interesting to reveal all the participants who were involved.â€ Just as Trump showed no remorse for his failed coup attempt, donâ€™t expect him to lose any sleep over failing to take down McConnell. Normal politicians would be embarrassed by their failures, but Trump is playing a numbers game. You miss all the shots you donâ€™t take. Trumpâ€™s targets for defeat within the GOP also include Rep. Liz Cheney and Georgia Gov. Brian Kemp. He wonâ€™t miss them all. 2021 was a bad year for a coup. Will we be so lucky in the New Year? Read more at The Daily Beast. Get our top stories in your inbox every day. Sign up now! Daily Beast Membership: Beast Inside goes deeper on the stories that matter to you. Learn more.
column4: McConnell Stops Another Coup Attempt as Trumpâ€™s Grip Keeps Slipping

A video of a Chinese and Indian soldiers introducing themselves to one another is making rounds on social media.

â€œMajor Keen Kumarâ€: The Indian soldier introduces himself as â€œMajor Keen Kumar,â€ and the Chinese soldier responds in kind by telling him his name is â€œSung Sung Do,â€
 

 According to Hindustan Times, the name â€œKeen Kumarâ€ is traditionally used as a nickname to conceal oneâ€™s identity. Similar names used to hide oneâ€™s identity include â€œLieutenant Keen,â€ â€œCaptain IM Smartâ€ and â€œCaptain Chatak Singh.â€ The undated video, which was reportedly shot near the India-China Line of Actual Control, shows the two soldiers facing each other with two banners in the background. It is unclear whether the name â€œSung Sung Doâ€ was also made up. Viewers have reveled at the Indian soldierâ€™s sense of humor. Journalist Aman Singh also shared the clip with the caption, â€œFinally Major Keen Kumar has been located. On the LAC. Well done.â€ 
 

 As for the viewers who were left confused, a Twitter user explained, â€œAn Indian Officer is â€˜KEENâ€™ to know the identity of the Chinese officer. So when asked what was the name of Indian Officer, our witty Major replied, â€˜I am Major â€˜Keenâ€™ Kumar.â€™â€
